slides.title: Introduction to Child Health
slides.content:
**Maintaining Child Health**

As an Anganwadi worker, you play a vital role in:
- Preventing diseases through immunization
- Early identification of sick children
- Health education to mothers
- Linking community with health services

**Topics Covered:**
- Immunization schedule
- Common childhood diseases
- When to refer to health facility
- Basic health checkups

**Remember:** Prevention is better than cure!

slides.title: Universal Immunization Programme
slides.content:
**Why Immunization?**

Vaccines protect children from serious diseases:
- Prevents death and disability
- Builds immunity
- Community protection
- Free of cost in government facilities

**Vaccine Preventable Diseases:**
- Tuberculosis (TB)
- Polio
- Diphtheria
- Pertussis (Whooping cough)
- Tetanus
- Hepatitis B
- Measles
- Pneumonia
- Diarrhea (Rotavirus)
- Japanese Encephalitis

**Your Role:**
- Maintain immunization register
- Track children due for vaccination
- Mobilize mothers for vaccination sessions
- Educate about importance of complete immunization

slides.title: Immunization Schedule - Part 1
slides.content:
**National Immunization Schedule**

**At Birth:**
- BCG (against TB) - one dose
- OPV 0 (Oral Polio Vaccine) - birth dose
- Hepatitis B - birth dose (within 24 hours)

**6 Weeks:**
- OPV 1
- Pentavalent 1 (DPT + Hepatitis B + Hib)
- Rotavirus 1 (against diarrhea)
- PCV 1 (Pneumococcal - against pneumonia)
- IPV 1 (Inactivated Polio Vaccine)

**10 Weeks:**
- OPV 2
- Pentavalent 2
- Rotavirus 2
- PCV 2

**14 Weeks:**
- OPV 3
- Pentavalent 3
- Rotavirus 3
- PCV 3
- IPV 2

slides.title: Immunization Schedule - Part 2
slides.content:
**National Immunization Schedule (Continued)**

**9-12 Months:**
- Measles-Rubella (MR) 1st dose
- PCV Booster
- Vitamin A (1st dose)
- JE 1 (Japanese Encephalitis - in endemic areas)

**16-24 Months:**
- DPT Booster 1
- OPV Booster
- MR 2nd dose
- JE 2 (in endemic areas)

**Every 6 Months (9 months to 5 years):**
- Vitamin A supplementation

**5-6 Years:**
- DPT Booster 2

**10 Years:**
- Tetanus and adult Diphtheria (Td)

**16 Years:**
- Td (Tetanus and adult Diphtheria)

**Important:** Complete all doses on time for full protection!

slides.title: Common Childhood Diseases
slides.content:
**Recognizing Common Illnesses**

**Diarrhea:**
- Loose watery stools, 3+ times/day
- Causes: Contaminated food/water, poor hygiene
- Danger signs: Sunken eyes, no tears, very thirsty
- Treatment: ORS, continue feeding, zinc tablets

**Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI):**
- Cough, cold, difficulty breathing
- Danger signs: Fast breathing, chest indrawing, blue lips
- Refer immediately if danger signs present

**Fever:**
- Normal: 98.6°F (37°C)
- Fever: Above 100°F (37.8°C)
- Causes: Infection, teething, etc.
- Danger signs: Fever >3 days, seizures, very high fever

**Skin Infections:**
- Scabies, ringworm, boils
- Maintain hygiene
- Refer for treatment

slides.title: Danger Signs in Children
slides.content:
**When to Refer IMMEDIATELY to Hospital**

**Newborn Danger Signs (0-2 months):**
- Not feeding well
- Feels cold or very hot
- Fast or difficult breathing
- Convulsions/fits
- Yellow palms and soles
- Bleeding from umbilicus

**Danger Signs in Older Children:**

**FAST BREATHING:**
- 2 months-1 year: >50 breaths/minute
- 1-5 years: >40 breaths/minute

**CHEST INDRAWING:**
- Lower chest goes in when breathing

**NOT ABLE TO DRINK:**
- Refuses to feed
- Vomits everything

**CONVULSIONS:**
- Fits/seizures

**BLOOD IN STOOL**

**UNCONSCIOUS OR LETHARGIC**

**Action:** Don't delay - refer immediately!

slides.title: Basic Health Checkups
slides.content:
**Regular Health Assessments**

**Monthly Checkups (0-6 years):**

**1. Weight and Height:**
- Measure and record
- Plot on growth chart
- Check if growing well

**2. General Appearance:**
- Active or lethargic?
- Skin - any rashes, paleness?
- Eyes - clear or yellow?
- Hair - healthy or brittle?

**3. Developmental Milestones:**
- Check age-appropriate skills
- Refer if delayed

**4. Immunization Status:**
- Check card
- Identify pending vaccines
- Mobilize for session

**5. Nutrition Assessment:**
- Check for malnutrition signs
- Counsel on feeding

**6. Vision and Hearing:**
- Simple screening tests
- Refer if problems detected

**Maintain proper records!**

slides.title: Home Visits and Counseling
slides.content:
**Effective Home Visits**

**When to Do Home Visits:**
- Newborn visit (within 7 days)
- Child absent from Anganwadi
- Missed immunization
- Malnourished child
- Sick child follow-up

**What to Check:**
- Living conditions
- Hygiene practices
- Feeding practices
- Child's health status
- Any problems faced by mother

**Counseling Skills:**

**DO:**
- Listen patiently
- Show respect
- Appreciate good practices
- Give practical advice
- Be supportive

**DON'T:**
- Criticize or scold
- Use difficult medical terms
- Force decisions
- Make empty promises

**Follow-up:** Regular visits build trust and ensure compliance.

slides.title: Linking with Health Services
slides.content:
**Coordination with Health System**

**Key Health Personnel:**

**ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife):**
- Conducts immunization sessions
- Antenatal checkups
- Delivery services
- Coordinate with ANM regularly

**ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist):**
- Community health worker
- Helps in health awareness
- Accompanies patients to hospital

**AWW-ASHA-ANM:**
- Work as a team
- Regular monthly meetings
- Plan health activities together

**Referral System:**
- Primary Health Centre (PHC)
- Community Health Centre (CHC)
- District Hospital

**Your Responsibility:**
- Identify and refer sick children
- Accompany if needed
- Follow-up after referral
- Maintain referral register

question.questionText: Which vaccine is given at birth to protect against Tuberculosis (TB)?
question.explanation: BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine is given at birth to protect against Tuberculosis (TB). It is given as a single dose in the left upper arm and leaves a small scar.
